title: Dick Reichle
text:
Richard Wendell Reichle (November 23, 1896 – June 13, 1967) was a <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player who appeared in 128 games for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> of <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) during the 1922 and 1923 seasons. Listed at and , he batted left-handed and threw right-handed. Reichle was also a <a href="college%20football">college football</a> player, and played in the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> (NFL) during the 1923 season.
Biography.
Reichle was a native of <a href="Lincoln%2C%20Illinois">Lincoln, Illinois</a>; he first attended <a href="Lincoln%20College%20%28Illinois%29">Lincoln College</a>, and later the <a href="University%20of%20Illinois">University of Illinois</a>. His college career was interrupted by service in the <a href="United%20States%20Navy">United States Navy</a> during World War I; he played for the <a href="1918%20Great%20Lakes%20Navy%20Bluejackets%20football%20team">1918 Great Lakes Navy Bluejackets football team</a> that won the <a href="1919%20Rose%20Bowl">1919 Rose Bowl</a>. Reichle was also a member of the <a href="1919%20Illinois%20Fighting%20Illini%20football%20team">1919 Illinois Fighting Illini football team</a>.
In a short professional baseball career, 1922 to 1924, Reichle was primarily an <a href="outfielder">outfielder</a> who also played some games as a <a href="first%20baseman">first baseman</a>. He appeared in 164 <a href="Minor%20League%20Baseball">minor league</a> games and 128 <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">major league</a> games.
Reichle's major league debut was on September 19, 1922, appearing for the <a href="Boston%20Red%20Sox">Boston Red Sox</a> against the <a href="Cleveland%20Indians">Cleveland Indians</a>; he went hitless in four <a href="at%20bat">at bat</a>s in a 7–4 loss. Reichle got his first major league hit the next day, singling against <a href="George%20Uhle">George Uhle</a> of the Indians in a 5–2 loss. With the <a href="1922%20Boston%20Red%20Sox%20season">1922 Red Sox</a>, Reichle went 6-for-24 for a .250 <a href="Batting%20average%20%28baseball%29">batting average</a> in six games with Boston.
Reichle played in 122 games with the <a href="1923%20Boston%20Red%20Sox%20season">1923 Red Sox</a>, a team that compiled a 61–91 record. On April 20, 1923, Reichle hit the only <a href="home%20run">home run</a> of his career, coming off of <a href="Waite%20Hoyt">Waite Hoyt</a> of the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees">New York Yankees</a>; it was also the first home run hit by a visiting player at <a href="Yankee%20Stadium%20%281923%29">Yankee Stadium</a>, which had officially opened two days earlier. For the season, Reichle batted .258 with 39 <a href="run%20batted%20in">RBI</a>s.
Overall, Reichle appeared in 128 major league games, all with the Red Sox, recording a .257 batting average with one home run and 39 RBIs. In 101 defensive appearances (99 in the outfield, 2 at first base) he posted a .978 <a href="fielding%20average">fielding average</a>.
Reichle played in six games with the <a href="1923%20Milwaukee%20Badgers%20season">1923 Milwaukee Badgers</a> of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> at right <a href="End%20%28gridiron%20football%29">end</a>. He was a second-team selection to the <a href="1923%20All-Pro%20Team">1923 All-Pro Team</a> by "<a href="Collyer%27s%20Eye">Collyer's Eye</a>".
After his brief professional sports career, Reichle pursued a career in insurance. Per his April 1942 draft registration card, he was employed by Investors Syndicate (present-day <a href="Ameriprise%20Financial">Ameriprise Financial</a>) in <a href="St.%20Louis">St. Louis</a>. Reichle died at the age of 70 in <a href="Richmond%20Heights%2C%20Missouri">Richmond Heights, Missouri</a>, a suburb of St. Louis.
